citations.narrative:
On the day of inspection, the licensee is exhibiting 229 mammals at their site and only approved for 200 under their
current exhibitor license. Additionally, four of those animals being exhibited are a dangerous animal species, wild canids
(fennec foxes) that are being exhibited upon inspection and, per facility representatives, one Group 6 nonhuman primate
(a spider monkey) had been exhibited since their last inspection, neither of these species are approved on their current
license.
Not obtaining approval for an increased number of animals, or additional types of dangerous species, may negatively
impact the animals’ health and well-being since the licensee’s facility, knowledge of the new species, and number of
employees has not been evaluated. The licensee must not exhibit animals that are not approved for on their current
license, in not only quantity but also any dangerous species, until approved for a license that includes a greater quantity
and the dangerous species listed above.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by July 6, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Patricia Laracuente, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.1(b)(2) 
   
Requirements and application 
On the day of inspection, the licensee is exhibiting 229 mammals at their site and only approved for 200 under their 
current exhibitor license. Additionally, four of those animals being exhibited are a dangerous animal species, wild canids 
(fennec foxes) that are being exhibited upon inspection and, per facility representatives, one Group 6 nonhuman primate 
(a spider monkey) had been exhibited since their last inspection, neither of these species are approved on their current 
license.  
 
Not obtaining approval for an increased number of animals, or additional types of dangerous species, may negatively 
impact the animals’ health and well-being since the licensee’s facility, knowledge of the new species, and number of 
employees has not been evaluated. The licensee must not exhibit animals that are not approved for on their current 
license, in not only quantity but also any dangerous species, until approved for a license that includes a greater quantity 
and the dangerous species listed above. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by July 6, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Patricia Laracuente, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
